newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: CRICKET-Vettori's future hinges on Fleming-Boock.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-Vettori's future hinges on Fleming-Boock.

text.p: HAMILTON, March 14 - Daniel Vettori's development as a left arm spinner of genuine class largely depends on how quickly new captain Stephen Fleming adjusts to the role of leading the New Zealand cricket team.
That is the opinion of Stephen Boock, the Otago left arm slow bowler, who played 30 tests for his country between 1978 and 1985.

Like most observers, Boock has been hugely impressed by 18-year-old Vettori, who became the youngest player in New Zealand test history when he appeared in the second test against England in Wellington last month.
But Boock worries that a young captain and a general lack of experience within a largely youthful national side may impede the Northern Districts teenager's advancement.

Fleming, 23, entered the second test against Sri Lanka in Hamilton today with just two appearances as New Zealand captain behind him -- the third test loss to England in Christchurch last month and the big win over Sri Lanka earlier this week in Dunedin.
He will take time adjusting to, and feeling comfortable with, the extra responsibilities of captaincy, and Boock said it was natural there would be a settling in period.
"Fleming will possibly develop as a leader and learn quickly. But he and Vettori need to become very close," Boock told NZPA.
"Fleming needs to be close to half a dozen players who are going to make up the core of the team for the next five to even 10 years.
"It is essential he knows what they are thinking and how they feel.
"There is little experience within the New Zealand side which at the moment is largely made up of a group of apprentices.
""There is so little knowledge on the field, and Daniel, who is an exciting prospect, will have to be a fast learner."
Boock noticed one or two minor points to arise during the Kiwis' test victory over Sri Lanka in Dunedin which he believes have to be addressed.
He thought that at times Fleming's communication with Vettori was not what it could have been.
He also cites the field placement of Vettori at deep backward square leg when veteran offspinner Dipak Patel was operating at Carisbrook as something which had not been thought through properly.
"He was taken away from the action when he should have been in it. He has to be in a position where he can communicate with Patel and so their paths cross at the end of every over.
"Without that sort of thing Daniel's progress may be inhibited; with them he will thrive."
Boock also believed that both Vettori and Patel were guilty of flattening their trajectory too readily once centurymaker Romesh Kaluwitharana started clubbing the ball freely on the fourth afternoon.
"They defended and retrenched too quickly, and the communication was poor.
"It is not a criticism. After all, New Zealand won the test match by a handsome margin but there is no game in which you can't analyse things to improve on."
The presence of Patel, 38, in the side as Vettori feels his way on the international stage is important.

They have roomed together since Vettori was pitched into the test team five weeks ago, with Patel acting as a guardian figure, offering advice, encouragement and the wisdom of almost 20 years as a professional cricketer in England and New Zealand.
But Patel's international days are unquestionably limited.
"I worry about who Daniel is going to learn from in the future," Boock said.
